data.title: Add a "released" signal to Slider
data.body:
Sliders should have a way to trigger something only after they have been released, not continuously while they are being dragged.

An example case would be for a computationally intensive operation that can't be done on every frame.

I tested the `released()` signal but it did not seem to work, at least with mouse dragging.

data.title: math2d cross product method not accesible
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Any. Godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Vector2().cross() method is defined in math2d.cpp but not accessible form engine itself.
3D counterpart: Vector3().cross() method works fine.

**Steps to reproduce:**
calling from within gdscript:
Vector2().cross(Vector2())
result in:
method not defined for Vector2

data.title: Improvements to containers.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Any. Godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
child nodes take on the parent containers Scale property so scaling the child node will only be overridden by the parent. creating a scalable UI is next to impossible since the child only respects the parents scale and not there own. This could be a bug but if not I would suggest having more flexibility. The ItemList node is a perfect example, why not have the grid container have similar functionality? 
**Steps to reproduce:**
Backstory time. Needed to create a dynamic grid of buttons, so started with a boxContainer. Ran into limitations really fast with that. Tried using a grid but ran into the scaling problem. Can't use a ItemList because it only accepts Textures. Only option would be to write a custom container, not the best route for new Users. Glad I'm not a new user but ya.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Add singleton instance to _Marshalls
data.body:
I need this because my bindings generator expects a static `get_singleton` method to be available for singleton types.

Other options would be to not expose this type at all to my bindings (if the type is irrelevant, which I don't know) or to use the script API to retrieve the instance.

data.title: Constant expressions are not optimized
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1, Windows 10 64 bits

Q&A thread: https://godotengine.org/qa/9647/calculation-of-local-variable-inside-a-function

I tried to add the following test to my GDScriptPerformance project, to verify how long it takes for Godot to execute the addition of constants. Usually, compilers optimize that so if the expression is completely constant it would be resolved as an assignment.
However, Godot doesn't seem to do that, even in release builds.

Results of the release build:
```json
{
  "name": "Add two constants",
  "time": 23
},
{
  "name": "Add 20 constants",
  "time": 267
}
```

Adding 20 constants is 10 times slower than adding 2 constants.

Tests performed (TODO add them to https://github.com/godotengine/godot-tests/blob/master/benchmarks/zylann/gdscript_microtests.gd):
```gdscript
#-------------------------------------------------------
const CONST01 = 0
const CONST02 = 0

func test_constants_addition():
	start("Add two constants")
	for i in range(0,ITERATIONS):
		var x = CONST01 + CONST02
	
	stop()

#-------------------------------------------------------
const CONST03 = 0
const CONST04 = 0
const CONST05 = 0
const CONST06 = 0
const CONST07 = 0
const CONST08 = 0
const CONST09 = 0
const CONST10 = 0
const CONST11 = 0
const CONST12 = 0
const CONST13 = 0
const CONST14 = 0
const CONST15 = 0
const CONST16 = 0
const CONST17 = 0
const CONST18 = 0
const CONST19 = 0
const CONST20 = 0

func test_constants_addition_extended():
	start("Add 20 constants")
	for i in range(0,ITERATIONS):
		var x = CONST01 + CONST02 + CONST03 + CONST04 + CONST05 + CONST06 + CONST07 + CONST08 + CONST09 + CONST10 + \
		        CONST11 + CONST12 + CONST13 + CONST14 + CONST15 + CONST16 + CONST17 + CONST18 + CONST19 + CONST20
	
	stop()
```

data.title: A visual way to distinguish editor helpers on the scene tree
data.body:
There is the classic confusion with collision shapes and other helper nodes because they look like normal ones on the scene tree, I think editor helpers may need a visual way as a hint that they are not "real" nodes.

I wonder if could be possible to make them slightly different, italic and darker/colored text, something that can be used on tools and plugins too.

data.title: More Polygon2D shapes/tools for prototyping?
data.body:
Hello,

Making some prototyping with Godot engine, I believe that it would be nice if we could:
- make easily regular shapes with Polygon2D (e.g. circle, rectangle, ...),
- import the polygon defined in Polygon2D in CollisionPolygon2D through the GUI,
- add some tools, such as extrusion, to make complex shape more easily,
- allow shapes with hole (e.g. rings)

It does not need to be a fully fledged vectorial editor, but I think a bit some more tools/shapes could help prototyping.

data.title: Drop old-fashioned hand-made memory functions
data.body:
Compilers these days are pretty good at providing optimized `memcpy()` and the like. They also have intrinsics (inlined) and even may have architecture-specific versions for greater performance.

So there is no point in keeping the **copymem.h/.cpp** stuff. It would be this way even if that _TODO_ had ever been realized.

Just use the standard library routines for this and you'll be safe.

data.title: Cannot change/initialized the shape of a collision polygon through code?
data.body:
Hello,

I am trying to do some prototyping with Godot Engine. So I'm trying to use Polygon2D and CollisionPolygon2D.

It seems that there is a lack of default shape for Polygon2D, so I needed to create a circular shape through code:
```
extends CollisionPolygon2D

const shape = Vector2Array()
var util = load("util.gd").new()
	
func _ready():
	for i in range(0,360,10):
		shape.append(util.pol2cart(deg2rad(i), 50)+get_pos())
	print(shape)
	set_polygon(shape)
```

Then, instead of using CollisionShape/Circle, I wanted to simply import the Polygon2D into a CollisionPolygon2D (as it would be nice thing to do later for more complex shape):
``` python
extends CollisionPolygon2D
func _ready():
        set_build_mode(0)
	set_polygon(get_node("/root/main_scene/Polygon2D").get_polygon())
```

That is not working very much. Note that Godot asked me to create a shape for the CollisionPolygon2D object in the Godot 2D Editor (that is the object selected in the 2D editor, in the screenshot below) ; then my script is expected to overwrite that shape. Here the results:
![2016-11-05 3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10520249/20029698/88b104fe-a34b-11e6-8748-ee0baa49bbdb.png)
It does look like that the Collision polygon has been overridden by my script (you can see the red circle on the game window, drawn by the debugger), though with an offset. 
However, when I move the red square with my keyboard (that have the square collision shape, shown in grey), the red circle is not making any collision (I can pass through it). Interestingly, if I go, with my square, near the polygon shape that I defined in the 2D Editor, I can experience collision with that polygon (I cannot pass through it).

Thus, it seems that there may be:
- a bug in the debugger,
- a problem with creating polygon by code for the CollisionPolygon2D object.

After that I try to simply copy paste the code that creates my circular polygon for my Polygon2D object into the CollisionPolygon2D object:

```
extends CollisionPolygon2D

var util = load("util.gd").new()
const shape = Vector2Array()

func _ready():
	for i in range(0,360,10):
		shape.append(util.pol2cart(deg2rad(i), 50)+get_pos())
	print(shape)
	set_polygon(shape)
```

Surprisingly, that does not work at all :/ when I run the game, the debugger shows no collision polygon for the object. However, if I move my red square, I can see that there is collision with the shape defined in the 2D editor.

I don't know if that is a bug or if it is me who do it wrong.
But if it is a bug, it may be quite problematic for when people want to make some prototyping with simple shape.

data.title: Clean/fix triangulation internals
data.body:
Drop unused variable
Remove commented-out code
Fix leak by using Vector instead of raw memory

data.title: Memory leak with circular reference in GDscript
Ability to create your own resource types
data.body:
**What do I mean?**

Well, since Resources are just data containers, this should not be too complex to achieve. What I mean is to, somehow, be able to create your own Resource type, making it possible to create data files and edit them within the editor.

**How would it work?**

My sincere apologies if it's not welcome to show how other engines do it, but I think it's interesting to exemplify. I will just not mention the framework/editor I'm talking about, but that's how one can create a Resource:

http://image.prntscr.com/image/fc4489a3b0104102974c6b08da2dd965.png

After compiling it, it's possible to edit the public properties (similar to export vars) of said Resource. Reminder: The Resource itself won't do any thing, it just stores data for the game to handle. The Resource's file extension could be fileName.resourceName.res.

Let's say I create a Resource type called Character and I name it George... Its filename would be george.character.res. There are other ways to name it, though (or maybe leaving it as field, so the user names it however they want).

**When would it be useful?**

That's a great way to make databases. One could make a --xml, json, ini or whatever-- the game would read and then would just create Resources for the game. Let's say I created a Weapon Resource, and a Character one. The Weapon Resource would contain: A string called Name, and a int called Damage. 

The Character Resource would contain: A string called Name, and a ResourceRef<Weapon> called Weapon. Then I could give the weapons a name and a damage. Also give the Character a name and a weapon.

Then, I could create a Sprite node that would be my character, with a ResourceRef<Character> and properly load its data. Not only set its weapon but the stats, appearence, or whatever I wanted.

I hope I'm clear and if there's already a feasible way to achieve this within Godot, let me know how.

data.title: Prevent to make UndoRedo for duplicate if no selected node
GDScript ignores duplicate keys in dictionaries
data.body:
If you type something like the following:

```gdscript
var d = {
    'key': 'value1',
    'key': 'value2'
}
print(d.key)
```

It will print `value2`, overriding the first definition.

This a problem because a typo can lead to hard to find bugs. The user might even think this is some "feature" and expect it to work with multiple keys in some way.

It's something that should be detected at parse-time and show as error right in the script editor when typing.

data.title: Fix scene tree drag & drop places node as child (#6912)
data.body:
The meta "_editor_collapsed" is no longer a part of a node, so i have updated the code to use "is_displayed_folded()" instead.

If a node was dropped above a certain node, instead of just being placed above it, it would end up as a child to the node above the place you dropped it if that node is unfolded and has children. I have fixed this so it now just gets placed above the node even if the above node is unfolded.

See #6912 for bug reference.
